template.title: üéØ Romcom Core Elements
template.content:
KEY INGREDIENTS:
‚Ä¢ Meet Cute - The spark that starts it all
‚Ä¢ Obstacle - What keeps them apart (internal fears, external circumstances)
‚Ä¢ Stakes - Why this relationship matters
‚Ä¢ Growth - How both characters change
‚Ä¢ Chemistry - The undeniable connection

REMEMBER: The audience needs to root for BOTH characters to find love.

template.title: üí≠ Theme & Tone Ideas
template.content:
POTENTIAL THEMES:
‚Ä¢ Learning to trust again
‚Ä¢ Work vs. life balance
‚Ä¢ Opposites attract
‚Ä¢ Second chances
‚Ä¢ Finding yourself through love
‚Ä¢ Breaking down walls

TONE NOTES:
‚Ä¢ Keep it warm and optimistic
‚Ä¢ Humor comes from character, not situations
‚Ä¢ Emotional truth over big comedy moments
‚Ä¢ Make the audience feel good

template.title: ‚ú® Character Development Tips
template.content:
PROTAGONIST DEVELOPMENT:
‚Ä¢ Give them a clear emotional wound/fear
‚Ä¢ Create a compelling goal beyond romance
‚Ä¢ Show their growth through actions, not words
‚Ä¢ Make their flaw create comedy naturally

LOVE INTEREST DEVELOPMENT:
‚Ä¢ They should challenge the protagonist
‚Ä¢ Give them their own complete arc
‚Ä¢ Avoid the 'perfect person' trap
‚Ä¢ Show why they fall for the protagonist

CHEMISTRY CHECKLIST:
‚Ä¢ Do they bring out each other's best/worst?
‚Ä¢ Do they have fun together?
‚Ä¢ Do they fight well together?
‚Ä¢ Do they make each other better people?

template.title: üé¨ Scene Writing Reminders
template.content:
DIALOGUE TIPS:
‚Ä¢ Give each character a unique voice
‚Ä¢ Subtext is everything - what they don't say
‚Ä¢ Banter should reveal character
‚Ä¢ Avoid exposition dumps

SCENE STRUCTURE:
‚Ä¢ Enter late, leave early
‚Ä¢ Every scene needs conflict/tension
‚Ä¢ Show, don't tell emotions
‚Ä¢ Use physical comedy sparingly

PACING NOTES:
‚Ä¢ Build romantic tension gradually
‚Ä¢ Don't rush the emotional beats
‚Ä¢ Alternate between comedy and heart
‚Ä¢ Save the biggest laughs for Act II

template.title: üåü Inspiration & References
template.content:
CLASSIC ROMCOM BEATS TO STUDY:
‚Ä¢ When Harry Met Sally - Best friends dynamic
‚Ä¢ The Princess Bride - Adventure + romance
‚Ä¢ Roman Holiday - Fish out of water
‚Ä¢ Sleepless in Seattle - Destiny and fate
‚Ä¢ Notting Hill - Class differences

MODERN EXAMPLES:
‚Ä¢ Crazy Rich Asians - Cultural specificity
‚Ä¢ The Big Sick - Real-world obstacles
‚Ä¢ To All the Boys - YA authenticity

REMEMBER: Study what works, don't copy. Find your unique voice within the genre.

template.title: üìù Development Questions
template.content:
ASK YOURSELF:
‚Ä¢ What's the worst thing that could happen to your protagonist in love?
‚Ä¢ What does your love interest need to learn about themselves?
‚Ä¢ What would make your audience cry happy tears?
‚Ä¢ How can you surprise without betraying expectations?
‚Ä¢ What makes this story uniquely yours?

STORY CHECKPOINTS:
‚Ä¢ Does every character serve the central romance?
‚Ä¢ Are the obstacles believable and relatable?
‚Ä¢ Does the ending feel earned, not just inevitable?
‚Ä¢ Would you want to watch this movie?

If you get stuck, go back to character motivation. What do they want? What are they afraid of? How does love challenge both?
